frame.name: Basis_for_attribute
frame.definition:
<def-root>A piece of information about a <fen>Landmark</fen> is presented as more accessible and useful for determining or communicating a similar type of information about the <fen>Trajector</fen>. In this construal of a situation, there is a (more) profiled element, the <fen>Trajector</fen>, and an un- or less profiled element, the <fen>Landmark</fen>. In combination with a schematically-defined <fen>Profiled_region</fen> (with a pre-defined relationship to the <fen>Landmark</fen>), the <fen>Landmark</fen> serves as the basis for understanding the status or location of the <fen>Trajector</fen>.
<ex><fex name="Trajector">The cat</fex> <t>in</t> <fex name="Landmark">the shed</fex> purred violently .</ex> <ex><fex name="Trajector">The shed</fex> <t>around</t> <fex name="Landmark">the cat</fex> shook .</ex> <ex>We 'll have to <fex name="Trajector">leave</fex> <t>before</t> <fex name="Landmark">noon</fex> .</ex> <ex>In the 1990s , though , <fex name="Trajector">the rate at which DNA could be read</fex> revved <t>into</t> <fex name="Landmark">high gear</fex> .</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Trajector
FE.definition: <def-root>The entity whose status or location is (generally) unknown, and whose status or location is established by examining the <fen>Profiled_region</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Landmark
FE.definition: <def-root>The entity, generally presupposed, whose status or location is known or knowable and which thus serves as a basis for understanding the status or location of the <fen>Trajector</fen> by locating it in a <fen>Profiled_region</fen> which has a particular relation to the <fen>Landmark</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Profiled_region
FE.definition: <def-root>The region which has a particular shape, orientation, size, and location (literal or metaphorical) with respect to the <fen>Landmark</fen>. The shape of the <fen>Profiled_region</fen> is virtually always incorporated in the target. This shaped region usually includes the location of the <fen>Landmark</fen>, as seen with <ment>in.prep, at.prep, on.prep</ment>, but may also do exactly the opposite, as with <ment>away from.prep</ment>.</def-root>
